description:
Dermatophilus congolensis is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Dermatophilus. It is a Gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic, and non-spore-forming actinomycete bacterium. Dermatophilus congolensis is the causative agent of a disease known as dermatophilosis or cutaneous streptothricosis, which primarily affects livestock such as cattle, sheep, and horses.

The bacterium has a characteristic branching, filamentous growth pattern and can form spore-like structures called zoospores, which are capable of dispersal and can contribute to the transmission and spread of the infection. Dermatophilus congolensis is found in tropical and subtropical regions and thrives in warm and humid environments.

The disease caused by this bacterium is characterized by the formation of crusty, scaly lesions on the skin of the affected animals. These lesions can lead to hair loss, skin inflammation, and secondary bacterial or fungal infections. Dermatophilosis can have significant economic and production impacts on livestock industries, and effective prevention and control measures are important in areas where the disease is endemic.
